electricity generation and distribution. Gaining access to a corporate network is a necessary step towards gaining access to an industrial control network, which is the ultimate target in successfully disrupting the grid. The RAT or similar software grants the attacker access to the corporate network, which then opens doors to a wider reconnaissance of the facility. RATs achieve this end often by tricking corporate personnel into granting the attack deeper network access; the trick can come in the form of a phishing email that prompts a corporate employee to give their network credentials or to download a seemingly innocuous file to their computer. In the end, this step affords the attacker deeper intrusion into a facility and puts the attacker one step closer to disrupting operations. Methods of combating delivery of a RAT range from having effective malware detection software to a prohibition on using USB drives or accepting files from untrustworthy sources.
(4) Install RAT: Secondary to the delivery of the RAT, the RAT must be installed. This typically occurs when an employee of the business unwittingly installs the RAT to the corporate network. This is often through a ‘social engineering' method of attack because it exploits human weakness to achieve an objective. An example of this would be sending what appears to be an email from an employee's friend, spouse, etc, that encourages the employee to download a file, such as a party invitation, whereas it is actually an email from the attacker with malware cloaked in a benign attachment. Another example of this would be an attack where the attacker ostensibly applies for a job by sending an application to human resources, but has embedded malware within the attached resume. To combat RAT installation, much like the methods discussed in the previous section, requires both employee education and file monitoring on the corporate network.
(5) Establish command-and-control connection: Once malware is successfully installed within a corporate network, the attacker utilises that malware to establish a command and control connection (CCC) back to an external server of the aggressor. It is at this point that the attacking party gains actionable and unauthorised access to a grid facility's corporate network. Having gained this access, the attacker can now monitor traffic on the corporate network, research files held on the network, harvest network user credentials such as passwords and critical facility codes, upload additional malware and so on. For facility defence at this level, a robust network firewall is essential because by monitoring all communication done with an external server a facility has a strong chance of detecting the attacker's activities.
(6) Deliver malware plugins: Building upon recently installed malware, the attacker will now deliver malware plugins. The purpose of additional plugins is to expand the range of network reconnaissance. An example of a malware plugin would be a keystroke logger, which functions as a recording device on an employee's computer that records each keyboard input and then transmits that keystroke record back to the attacker. Much like the antidote for other forms of malware, the target can defend against this manner of intrusion with sophisticated and updated malware detection software.
(7) Harvest credentials: Similar to the delivery of malware plugins, the attacker will pursue a strategy of credential harvesting, or, in lay terms, username and password theft. This is a critical step, because by obtaining the login credentials of individuals with broad network authority access the attacker can expand their reach throughout the corporate network and, most importantly, into the industrial control system network. This is a significant step towards both the disruption of the grid and the attack's ability to navigate network traffic largely undetected. In effect, the attacker subsumes the grid control authority and access of an individual or individuals with the ability to alter conditions of the industrial control network.
(8) Lateral movement and target identification on the corporate network: This stage marks when an attacker effectively maps an entire corporate network, or at least its essential components. This step may require months of execution, but by the end of this phase the attacking party should have full understanding of and access to relevant servers, employee work stations, telecommunication infrastructure, power supply and so on. Aside from monitoring for suspicious activity, network defence should make efforts to compartmentalise network functions as a means of thwarting comprehensive network movement. Another strategy to detect intrusion at this level is to establish what are known as honeypots, or network decoys, which are network files that serve no useful purpose and would not be accessed by any employees in the normal course of their work. If a series of these decoy files were accessed, this would suggest some form of nefarious reconnaissance is underway.
(9) Lateral movement and target identification on Industrial Control System (ICS) network: This is the stage of the attack in which the attacking party jumps from the corporate network to the industrial control network, ie the systems that provide operational control of the facility's power generation and distribution network. An industrial control system functions like a traditional, manual system except that at key points of its operation it receives digital commands from either automated operating instructions or human input. For example, a hydroelectric power plant may continue producing power through the physics of water-pressure-driven turbines until a human actor, interacting with the facility through a digital control system like a computer or more basic workstation, gives an instruction to the plant control system to either cease power production or ramp it up, or to do something else. These command systems can take many forms, but a basic form is a human--machine interface workstation, which would likely be a laptop type device that is directly connected to an industrial control system, like a programme that has the authority to adjust the speed of a hydroelectric turbine. Within the physical world of the facility, a properly credentialed employee would be able to walk up to this human--machine interface workstation and send a command to the control system for the turbine to alter its operation. In the case of an outside attack on the grid, the attacker would gain access to this workstation remotely and use it to give a command as if the attacker were physically present at the facility. At this stage, an attacker would not yet know how to initiate an attack, but this would be the time when the attacker explores the industrial control system network in an attempt to uncover its vulnerabilities and to identify targets necessary to disrupt the facility's operation. To prevent this stage from occurring, the facility should configure a third, intermediate network between the corporate network and the industrial control system network, wherein the intermediate network acts as holding centre for cross-network traffic to be evaluated. This is akin to a decontamination room that is used when a virologist exits a secure room where they have been studying a dangerous pathogen; the virologist is not permitted to exit a possibly contaminated room without first going through a decontamination room and then, upon approval, being released from that room back into a normal, presumably virus-free environment. While this is not a foolproof method of defending an industrial control system network, it does ensure that an attacker's efforts are more closely scrutinised. Of note, this measure is not the same as an air-gap system, ie a system that separates the industrial control system network from the corporate network. It has been demonstrated that an air-gap system is not practical nor is it as secure as it may seem in theory.
(10) Develop malicious firmware: Once an attacker has explored the industrial control system network, uncovered its vulnerabilities, and established control system targets, the attacker will develop a weapon appropriate for disrupting those targets. The weapon will be some form of malicious firmware. The attacker does not require access to either the corporate or the industrial control system network during the malicious firmware development stage; rather, the actor will perform this process completely externally to the target facility. However, the attacker may test the malicious firmware on other, similar targets as a means of fine-tuning the efficacy of the weapon. This brings us back to the issue of Ukraine. Ukraine has been and is the testing ground for a host of cyber weapons, and it is generally accepted that malware developed to strike grid-critical facilities are often tested in Ukraine before being executed against their actual target.
(11) Deliver data destruction malware: Preceding an attack, the aggressor will utilise its access to the facility networks (both corporate and industrial control systems) to upload data-destruction malware. The purpose of this malware is to preschedule the deletion of pertinent data that would be relevant to restoring a system's operational integrity. Although the deletion itself is not formally the attack, it complements the attack by frustrating the assessment of what is occurring during an attack as well as hobbling a defensive response to an attack. The only means of confronting this stage of the attack is to maintain robust scanning measures for malware.
(12) Schedule uninterruptable power supply disruption: Grid facilities rely a continuous operation of critical systems during normal operation. During an attack it is even more important to maintain power as a means of ameliorating the disruption. However, using harvested credentials, an attacker will preschedule the termination of otherwise uninterruptable power supply (UPS) sources so that it becomes easier to execute multiple attacks, to do so undetected and to debilitate restoration efforts. A method of combating this tactic is to isolate UPS systems from the corporate and/or industrial control system networks.
(13) Trip breakers: After months or even years of preparation, the attack finally commences. Using access to the industrial control system network and credentials that enable the manipulation of human--machine interface systems, the attacker will issue a command to open the breakers within the facility's power generation and distribution system. The end result will be the disruption of power to a wide range of consumers, measurable in the hundreds of thousands or millions. As discussed above, it is essential to tightly control user access to the industrial control system network, both internally and externally. At this stage, the attack will become known to the facility and corrective measures will likely ensue. For this reason, the attacker will then commence additional attacks to derail any attempted defensive procedures.
(14) Sever connection to field devices: Knowing that a facility control centre will take immediate steps to close the breakers and restore power to the grid, the attack will trigger malware that disrupts power converters and cuts communication between the facility control centre and its substations. The result is that breakers cannot be closed remotely over the network and can only be closed manually. While this may sound like an easy solution, the larger the attack, the longer manual restoration will require. A robust system for monitoring industrial control system network traffic and simulated attack and restoration exercises are necessary to avoid this scenario.
(15) Telephony denial-of-service attack: At a corporate network level, measures will immediately commence to register consumer complaints and formulate a company action plan. As with most power outages, consumers will begin calling the corporate call centre to report a disruption, only now the attacker will flood the call centre with a telephony denial-of-service attack so that the call centre effectively drowns in fake calls and is rendered incapable of addressing legitimate consumer complaints. In order to avoid this frustration, a power company should partner with its phone service provider to develop a means of filtering legitimate from fraudulent calls.
(16) Disable critical systems via UPS: At this stage, step 12 becomes relevant as the attacker's prescheduled power outages begin to wreak havoc on the response effort. Commonly, facility operators will take steps to rely on backup power systems, but here they will find them suspended and useless. This will add more chaos to an already chaotic situation.
(17) Destroy critical system data: Finally, with the power disrupted, control stations neutered and the power company thrown into a technical maelstrom, the attacker will cut the jugular of the facility. With vast access to the corporate and industrial control system networks, the attack will trigger malware that systematically deletes data critical to the operations of the facility. This step of the attack has the potential to make internal restoration of power impossible. Moreover, with the physical components of the facility effectively turned off and the digital systems wiped of all critical data, the likelihood of power restoration in the foreseeable future becomes questionable at best.
(18) Physical destruction of plant systems: Although the 17 prior steps are adequate to turn the lights out, another element of a successful attack warrants attention. Had the attacker initiated a command that caused a power surge sufficient to burn up necessary critical infrastructure, then not even manual restoration would remedy the disruption. Under this scenario, power could only be restored by installing new equipment, which, depending on the severity of the attack, could be a protracted solution that requires years of work.
### Post-mortem or restoration If a large-scale cyber attack does come to fruition, what might be some of the second-order effects? One example comes from a situation that occurred in Wyoming in February 2017, when a strong windstorm knocked down a large number of power lines. Because of the inoperable power lines, along with heavy snow, power was not restored for approximately a week. Generators initially powered sewage treatment facilities, but eventually the generators began to fail and as a result sewage began backing up. To avoid wastewater flooding into homes, the area's water supply was cut off. One needs only a modest imagination to consider the impact that a similar situation might have in New York City, Los Angeles, London or any other major metropolitan area. And, to make matters worse, curtailment of clean water could be only one of many challenges resulting from lost power. This grave concern prompted Lawrence Susskind at Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)'s urban systems department to remark, ‘Millions... could be left with no electricity, no water, no public transportation, and no waste disposal for weeks (or even months).... No one can protect critical urban infrastructure on their own'.
Combined with the social and economic turmoil that could be caused by a crippling grid attack, there could be further difficulties caused by the disruption to supply chains that would be necessary to restore power. At an MIT facility doing work on wind turbine power generation, a mechanical failure to the turbine took almost three months to fix because a necessary part had to be developed and delivered from Germany. Expand a situation of this type across an entire grid system, and it could take years to return all systems to normal working order. This sort of dismal situation is known as a black start, and it could prove extremely difficult to overcome. Moreover, one need to only look at the present challenges created by the COVID-19 viral pandemic to appreciate how delicate these critical infrastructure systems are when placed under unexpected and severe stress. An attack on the grid resulting in prolonged power loss would in many ways mirror, and in some ways far exceed, the disruptions presently occurring as a result of the virus pandemic.
A black start situation is one where power must be restored under circumstances where available power is already limited. It is akin to jumping a car battery by directing power from a live battery to the dead battery using jumper cables. Under the direst of grid attack scenarios, there may be too few live batteries, so to speak, to restore power swiftly before second-order effects begin unfolding. Thus, anyone tasked with mitigating a cyber attack against the grid must recognise that it is equally important to prepare for the possibility of a successful cyber attack. Consideration of the kinds of preparations needed for what comes in the wake of a successful cyber attack against the grid go far beyond the scope of this article; however, they should be given concern by the reader. Ultimately, the aim of any grid defence policy is to avoid a black start scenario, but it is critical to develop protocols both on a policy level and at an engineering level to extricate those affected by an attack as quickly as possible. Otherwise, the task of restoring power may become subsumed by larger social and economic implications.
## 5. Attack mitigation and the future ### 5.1. An insurance programme Cyber attacks, in particular those that compromise critical infrastructure like the grid, are costly. The losses to consumers and/or business impacted by a cyber Journal of Energy & Natural Resources Law 153 attack may be measured in the billions of dollars. For instance, the NotPetya cyber attack, which was a form of ransomware that emerged in 2017 principally in Ukraine but with effects felt globally, resulted in approximately $10 billion in worldwide damages.¹²⁴ This is troubling for three reasons: first, economic damages can result in the bankruptcy of companies instrumental to any number of life's facets; second, if a company survives the monetary toll of a cyber attack, it will often pass along these damages and the cost of corrective measures to consumers; and, third, inflicting economic damage is an incentive on the part of a cyber aggressor to pursue cyber warfare in the first place.
Instituting a policy that both ameliorates financial losses from cyber attacks and mitigates the incentive to commence them is a prudent measure. In light of the scale of potential economic damages caused by cyber attacks, the only entity with the wherewithal to absorb such losses is likely the federal government. The risk posed by cybersecurity attacks, particularly those aimed at the grid and other critical infrastructure, are not dissimilar to the sorts of risks that emerged following the 11 September 2001 terrorist attacks. After the 9/11 attacks, the federal government enacted the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act to provide a backstop to private insurers in the event of losses resulting from catastrophic terrorism.¹²⁵ This was an important response to the 9/11 attacks because acts of war exclusions, ie losses suffered as a result of war-making activities, have been common to insurance contracts for over a century.¹²⁶ Thus, if cyber attacks cannot be shown to fall within an act of war exclusion for purposes of insurance coverage, the insured parties must bear the burden of those losses without an insurance backstop.
Cyber attack-related insurance coverage accounted for approximately $2 billion in 2018.¹²⁷ This figure is expected to rise.¹²⁸ Should cyber attacks continue to evolve as they have in recent years, they will increasingly take on the look and feel of war-making activities, particularly those attacks that are attributable to a state sponsor. The federal government can bolster the private insurance market and strengthen the resiliency of the companies comprising critical infrastructure, such as the grid, by becoming a financial backstop. In light of the fact that the Terrorism Risk Insurance Act is expiring in 2020, it makes the most sense to renew it and amend it to expand coverage for cyber attack risk.
This approach will not be without obstacles, however. Cyber attacks can be difficult to measure in scope, and frequently the responsible party and that party's motivation for the attack are challenging to discern. For instance, if a company is hacked and that hack results in a ransom of private user data, and the company pays the ransom but cannot show that the attack was anything more than common thievery, then should that company be eligible for federal insurance? The most likely answer is no. For critical infrastructure entities, like grid operating facilities, this would not be a hard argument to make because infrastructure like the grid is so critical to modern life that attacks against it would almost invariably constitute a national security breach.
## 5.2. More warriors Beyond mitigating the financial strain of a grid attack, we must focus on rapidly and dramatically expanding our defensive workforce. Presently, the United States has about 720,000 cybersecurity workers, and while this may seem like a large number it leaves a shortfall of approximately 314,000 workers. According to a survey conducted by the Center for Strategic & International Studies, ‘[information technology] decision makers across eight countries found that 82 percent of employers report a shortage of cybersecurity skills and 71 percent believe this talent gap causes direct and measurable damage to their organizations’.¹²⁹ Moreover, it is expected that by 2022 the scale of the cybersecurity workforce shortage will be nearly 1.8 million unfilled positions.¹³⁰ There is simply no way to adequately defend the grid, and the rest of our digital vulnerabilities, with a cyber workforce that is lacking.
The nature of cyber threats is that they grow in number and sophistication in a nonlinear fashion, whereas hiring individuals to combat cyber attacks is limited by linear patterns. In other words, even if hiring occurs at a rate that results in a surplus of cybersecurity workers, the growing scale of the threat will still frequently outpace it. Yet we are presently nowhere near a surplus of employees, and it is crippling our ability to confront the possibility of large-scale grid disruption.
Public resources must be immediately directed to the education and training of cybersecurity workers. Computer engineering has been in ascendance as a profession for many years, but emphasis on cybersecurity has typically taken a back seat to emphasis on software development. In the survey discussed above, the same information technology decision makers indicated that only about one in four education programmes prepared students to enter the cybersecurity industry.¹³¹ If the United States is to prepare for the present and growing danger of major social disruption resulting from a grid failure, then it must put more boots on the ground. Federal grant programmes, increased training, employer incentives, tax credits for cybersecurity trainees and so on are essential. Although most of these individuals will not serve in the United States military, their jobs will be in large measure critical to the national security of the United States.
In the United Kingdom, the government recently rolled out a Cyber Retraining Academy to give individuals – some without any technology experience – the insights, tools and methods needed to help bridge the workforce gap. The United States government would be wise to follow the lead of its North Atlantic cousin by expanding the depth ¹²⁹ William Crumpler, ‘The Cybersecurity Workforce Gap’ (Center for Strategic and International Studies, 29 January 2019) www.csis.org/analysis/cybersecurity-workforce-gap accessed 14 March 2020.

The same is true for the United States Cyber Challenge and its high-school-level cybersecurity camps. These programmes warrant dramatic expansion and the requisite funding. In the end, the positions in demand are well-paying jobs that offer the chance to provide meaningful defence from a potentially existential threat, so the employee incentive is notable. However, our information technology workforce must be educated and reoriented so that enterprising technophiles seek to defend their country rather than produce the latest app for dog walking services.
### Sharing is caring An integral part of defending the grid is to share information about attacks. When cyber attacks first emerged as issues of concern, cyber intrusions were frequently met with an overwhelming urge to keep them quiet and hope that they would go away. As everyone now knows, this is impossible. Thus, many impacted parties are now openly disclosing when they are victims of an attack, and they are seeking assistance from outside parties. This is a dramatic improvement, but more must be done if the grid is to be optimally protected.
Electric grid operators, regulators, insurance companies and others are beginning to share information on attacks and potential takes. However, a voluntary sharing programme is not ideal. By putting into law the Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act (CISA), Congress took a step in the right direction, but did not go far enough because the programme is voluntary. Voluntary sharing of information leaves open the possibility that critical information may be withheld. Should critical information be withheld, it will result in a less effective response and a deficient understanding of the threat. That being said, CISA, which is managed by the Department of Homeland Security (DHS), does effectively aggregate and communicate threat information.
Thus, this article recommends that CISA be amended to mandate the sharing of information and likewise to impose commercial sanctions on those companies that fail to disclose evidence of a cyber attack. This would remove the discretionary component of information sharing from private entities, streamline their disclosure process and put the federal government in a better informed position. The present situation is akin to not requiring, by law, that medical facilities report cases of highly infectious diseases to the Centers for Disease Control. In the same way that healthcare providers are mandated by law to report to the Centers for Disease Control, critical infrastructure companies, like those managing the grid, should be required by law to report to DHS when they suspect a cyber threat or are victims thereof.
### Don't forget the little guy As discussed earlier, the bulk power system, which comprises the major utility companies in the United States, is fairly robust in its management of cyber threats. However, the smaller utility companies that do not comprise the bulk power system, known as the B Monarch smaller distribution grids, are lagging significantly in their management of grid attacks. It is proper that the grid’s major players receive the most attention from cybersecurity experts, but left unattended, the small distribution grids will become the desired target of cyber aggressors. In much the same way that security is provided for large-scale terrorist targets, like the Super Bowl or a presidential inauguration, the major power distributors receive the most concern. While the threat of an attack on a high-profile target is palpable, it is far more likely that softer targets will be struck. The grid can be viewed in much the same way, with one distinct difference: by targeting smaller, less well-defended grid targets, attackers can increase their likelihood of success and increase their understanding of how to strike the bulk power system.
To confront this weakness, Congress should expand oversight of the bulk power system to include the smaller distribution network. The present regulatory arrangement creates a two-tiered security scheme wherein the major utility players are closely scrutinised and heavily supported by federal expertise while the small distribution network is left much to its own defences. This type of system unintentionally makes the job of cyber attackers easier because it promotes an image that the most effective way to disrupt the grid is to go after the smaller networks. In other words, if Congress wittingly creates vulnerability in the grid by focusing most of its energy on a certain element of it, it will invite cyber aggressors to strike those soft targets.
In addition to expanded oversight, the federal government should subsidise cybersecurity measures for small distribution operators and help them develop a standard protocol for cyber defence. If small distribution networks are brought under the umbrella of a robust federal management system, then attackers will be forced to compete with the cyber expertise provided by the government. However, it is critical to note that although an oversight system and some type of standard operating protocol for threat assessment and defence are warranted, they should not come with requirements to standardise equipment, software, etc. Part of what gives the grid some inherent defence is its complexity and diversity. If the grid becomes more standardised and aggregated, this could make it more fragile because the more interconnected and less diverse the grid becomes the more easily it can be attacked on a large, disruptive scale. Therefore, the federal government must balance oversight that is helpful against requirements that might homogenise the grid to the point of increasing its vulnerability.^[133]^ ## 5.5. Activate university research and development One of the United States’ achievements is its vast, impressive and impactful university system. By subsidising research and development at a university level, the United States greatly enriched its economy and its people during the last half-century. This same system needs to be called upon to meet the challenge of cyber defence, particularly for existential risks like a large-scale grid disruption.
Programmes currently exist on this front through the National Science Foundation; however, Congress should act to expand funding in this area.^[134]^ Federal funding at a ^[133] Govindarasu (n 33).

Journal of Energy & Natural Resources Law 157 university level can take two principal forms. First, individual students can seek scholarships designed exclusively to fund their pursuit of academic credentials in the cybersecurity realm. Second, universities can obtain grants that provide support for entire academic programmes dedicated to both educating cybersecurity specialists and providing the latest research and analysis on cybersecurity threats.
Aside from direct federal funding, the government can provide tax incentives to potential university donors that promote greater emphasis on cybersecurity. Endowment contributions typically come in two forms, either an unrestricted contribution that the university can use towards a project of its choosing or a restricted contribution that must be used by the university according to the dictates of the donor. As most university donations are made to non-profit institutions, they are already tax deductible. However, the federal government can take the step, through the tax code, of providing a tax credit for restricted donations made towards further research and development in the cybersecurity space. This added incentive could provide additional endowment support for the expansion of cybersecurity defence, which by extension will promote stronger cybersecurity defence throughout various economic sectors.
Some may balk at the notion that preferential treatment is provided to funding cybersecurity measures at the university level. Obviously, money is a finite resource and a dollar dedicated to cybersecurity is a dollar not received by a cancer research facility, a law school an art programme, etc. This is a valid critique of this recommendation. However, unlike the aforementioned departments, and many others, cyber defence research goes to the heart of an existential threat facing Western societies. As discussed in earlier sections, under a worst-case scenario wherein the US electric grid is disrupted for months (or perhaps longer), the consequences could be so dire as to upend even the most common assumptions about daily life. In other words, we should fund cyber defence as if our lives depended on it, because they most likely do.
## 5.6. New tech – Internet of Things, automation and disaggregation The grid is not a static system; rather, it is evolving technologically every day. This attribute is both a blessing and a curse. It is a curse because it makes securing the grid more difficult, as each protective measure grows obsolete in a short period of time. It is also a curse because it is sometimes hard to imagine how a future grid may operate and what weaknesses it may have. Nonetheless, this situation can be a blessing and an opportunity, because it gives all of those involved with grid security an opportunity to use technology developments to strengthen it. But we must be mindful of using new technology to improve grid security, and regrettably that is not occurring presently.
There is much talk of a smart grid system being built upon the traditional grid system.^[135]^ This is, in effect, the digitisation and interconnection of the traditional grid into a grid system that more closely resembles the Internet. The smart grid relies on ‘near-instantaneous communication of information’ about grid elements, from the operation of a hydroelectric plant to the energy usage of a home refrigerator.^[136]^ B Monarch Sometimes called the Internet of Things, smart grid devices designed to monitor and control energy supply and demand are spreading rapidly across modern life.¹³⁷ It is anticipated that by 2025 there will be 75 billion Internet of Things devices worldwide.¹³⁸ The Internet of Things is a large universe, which includes anything from fitness trackers to autonomous farm equipment, but within it is a subset of devices that comprise the smart grid. These devices include connected appliances such as ovens and refrigerators, grid-connected thermostats, lighting systems for homes or businesses and so on.¹³⁹ These devices will be able to communicate energy supply and demand throughout the vast grid, and will interact with the traditional grid in ways that are yet unimaginable. One such imagined world is a future energy cloud system where power generation and distribution occurs across a network that includes sources from traditional power generation like coal-fired plants to home solar power generation, all of which moves across a network of power distribution akin to information technology cloud computing.¹⁴⁰ The disaggregated energy network of the future may offer untold advantages over the existing grid, such as reduced carbon emissions, greater efficiency and new sources of energy. However, without a security protocol in place to drive the development of smart devices, energy clouds, power distribution automation and so on, the cyber threat will loom larger and larger over the grid as we move into this increasingly digital energy network. Therefore, it is essential that the emerging technologies on this front have legally mandated security protocols to ensure their development advances with an eye towards making the grid stronger, not weaker. If the American entrepreneurial spirit builds a smarter grid in the years to come, it will have been in vain if it simply makes a smarter yet more vulnerable grid network. Thus, it is entirely appropriate for Congress to regulate this emerging market in a manner that does not allow innovation to trump security. The time to get this issue right is now, not ten years from now, and failing to do so will only worsen the risk that our grid could suffer a devastating attack.
## 5.7. Si vis pacem, para bellum ('If you want peace, prepare for war') The previous sections have all highlighted methods that promote cyber defence, but cyber offence is an important consideration when protecting the grid. Continued efforts by the United States military to develop cyber offensive capability can act as a deterrent to any outside aggressor that may be considering an attack on the US grid. However, there are areas for improvement on the offensive side of this issue.

Journal of Energy & Natural Resources Law 159 First, cyber warfare is presently a largely undefined realm of military engagement. Moreover, it is largely conducted in secret. These are not helpful characteristics. In order for offensive capabilities to serve as a deterrent to potential grid attacks, cyber aggressors must understand the scope of the United States’ abilities. This situation is not dissimilar to military shows of force, such as displaying the proficiency of new aircraft, disclosing the strength of the nuclear arsenal, establishing bases in tactically relevant locations and so on. If it is known to outside aggressors that the United States military stands ready to launch a far more devastating cyber attack should one be launched against the United States, then the likelihood of such an attack will diminish. On the other hand, if outside parties do not fear the prospect of an American reprisal, then they may feel bolder in their efforts to strike at critical infrastructure such as the grid.
Along these same lines, the military must map out clear rules of engagement. Presently, it is unknown what kind of attack would warrant a military response. For instance, should a modest strike against the grid occur, does this warrant an escalated cyber attack against the agitating party (assuming that party can be identified)? Or, perhaps, such a strike would warrant a traditional, kinetic military strike, such as a missile aimed at the aggressor’s critical infrastructure? Another option still is economic sanctions. Some have even suggested that a massive cyber attack against the United States, for example a nationwide grid attack, would warrant a military response that involves nuclear weapons. All of these are possible scenarios in part because it is unclear how the United States will engage should it be the victim of a massive cyber attack. This is not helpful. Most parties know that engaging the United States will result in some kind of a response, but without clear rules of engagement, the world is left open to too much dangerous conjecture and speculation. The Department of Defense should set out immediately to develop a comprehensive set of cyber rules of engagement that complement the existing rules of engagement.
## 5.8. A never-ending struggle In the end, no list of solutions for confronting the possibility of an existential grid attack is adequate over a long enough time horizon. This threat is evolving daily and will continue to evolve at a rapid pace for years to come – perhaps in perpetuity. As the grid becomes more complex and the threats against it more manifold and numerous, the only appropriate remedy is to invest all necessary resources into forestalling the worst. The stakes are simply too high for the modern way of life to allow even a slight chance of large-scale grid disruption, and yet that is where we find ourselves presently. The grid may not come under attack tomorrow, or even within the next year or decade, but eventually it is likely to be hit in a devastating manner, and we will be forced to confront the prospect of a black start. The toll this may take on our society could be irreparable. Thus, it is important to appreciate that the threat we face is likely not to abate so long as we have a grid that is vulnerable to existential disruption. And it is unlikely we will ever have a fully impregnable grid. We must, therefore, accept the scale of this threat and continue to innovate, through technology and policy, new ways of meeting it.
## 6. Conclusion The world in the digital age is a dangerous place. Numerous benefits have been bestowed by the technological revolution, but it has also exposed vulnerabilities that would have been unthinkable a generation ago. In no circumstances is this more obvious than in our daily need for electricity. In short, our lives rely on an uninterrupted supply of electricity as much as they rely on clean water. Yes, a lack of clean water will kill us, but a lack of electricity for more than a few days has the potential to destroy nearly every facet of modern life. The electric grid is under a relentless barrage of attacks, and those attacks are growing more sophisticated by the day. It stands to reason that sooner or later, one of these attacks will succeed, and when it does it could throw our society into darkness. Because of the consequences that may unfold in the wake of a grid attack, we must urgently take all necessary steps to mitigate the risk of grid failure. This requires all shareholders of this issue to stay informed, stay alert and invest the time and energy that is warranted to buttress the security of this critical lynchpin of the modern way of life.
